21035551.review:
The Bug Butcher is an interesting arcade shooter where you can only shoot up. An interesting effect of this idea is that you must get underneath your enemies to kill them, but that also put you in a compromised position as if the enemies will also be in position to land on you and do damage. The game isn't too complex. You hold down the shoot button, building up your combo meter for a high score while building up a power meter so you can unleash your special attack. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TNHe17ejeds
The visuals are nice with detailed and well animated 2d sprites, and the game has a good sense of humor about it. The music and sound effects are of a great quality that helps compliment it's visuals.

Although my time with the game is short (as of this review) I had a good time. It's an interesting take on the arcade shooter genre and at a low cost as well.

21034931.review:
[i]~Key provided by developer/publisher. This does not affect my review.~[/i]
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=618734384
Tags: Indie, Action, Shoot ‘Em Up, Co-op, Singleplayer, Arcade, Local Co-Op, Fast-paced, Cartoony, Sci-fi, Difficult, Great Soundtrack, Bullet Hell.

[h1]Introduction:[/h1]
The Bug Butcher is an Indie Arcade shoot ‘em up developed and published by Awfully Nice Studios .
[i]
The core mechanics hold old ties from the classic arcade shooter “Super Pang” where you shoot vertically, but with modern day twists. You are Harry, a brash and tenacious exterminator who has a knack for decimating bugs. [/i]

[h1]What I noticed at a first glance:[/h1]
[list][*]The controls are very tight and are simple enough for new players and complex enough for those who wish to go more in depth.
[*]It’s a 2D, side scrolling game with a twist: instead of shooting across the screen at enemies, you shoot vertically. 
[*]Unforgiving difficulty that punishes you when you mess up. Not unfair; if you die, it was most certainly your fault.
[*]The power-ups. There is a great variety of these, ranging from increased damage, attack speed, and freezing enemies. There are also weapons that can spawn in crates, each with its own advantages.
[*]Tons of available upgrades to increase different stats and perks.
Impressive soundtrack and sound design in general. Electronic, sci-fi music mixed with the pew pew pew of your laser gun.
[*]There are 3 game modes. Arcade missions act as a campaign mode with 30 levels. There is a set amount of time/waves of enemies that spawn. Panic (singleplayer) is a sungleplayer survival mode and Panic (co-op) is survival with local co-op enabled.
[*]Enemies varies depending on level. Each has their own attack patterns, which easy to learn, making them somewhat predictable (and killable)
[*]Cartoony, light-hearted art style that makes pest control in space seem more appealing then you ever thought it could be.	
[*]Levels are confined to a small space. I would enjoy a more open, free game mode where exploration was mixed with alien pest control. This may just be me, but I really enjoy games with certain aspects of freedom that allow the player to create his/her own unique experience.
[*]Replay value to get achievements and beat your old scores.[/list]

[h1]Summary[/h1]
I was impressed with the quality of this game. The controls are tight and the difficulty is unforgiving. If you have any interest in arcade shooters or games with big guns and lasers, I would highly recommend you at least check out the demo. 

[h1]My implemented rating system:[/h1]
[strike]Run away! 1-2/10
Handle with caution… 3-4/10
Buy on sale: 5-6/10[/strike]
[h1]Every day purchase: 7-8/10[/h1]
[strike]Must buy: 9-10/10[/strike]

[h1]This game’s rating: 7.5/10. A great buy at the regular price of $8 or lower on sale.[/h1]
http://store.steampowered.com/app/350740

21031222.review:
Scorecard:
http://i.imgur.com/olMKRw4.png

Full review with screenshots:
http://www.techfreshness.com/game-review-the-bug-butcher/

[table]
    [tr]
        [th]Feature[/th]
        [th]Y/N/Rating[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Aspect Ratios[/td]
        [td]Menu UI messy beyond 4:3-16:9, still playable[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Triple Monitor[/td]
        [td]Possible[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Framerate Cap[/td]
        [td]144+[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Performance[/td]
        [td]Just Fine[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Options[/td]
        [td]Almost None (Audio Vol/Toggles)[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Key Rebinding[/td]
        [td]Yes, Incomplete[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Controller Support/Rebinding[/td]
        [td]Yes, No[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Local Co-op[/td]
        [td]Endless Co-op Mode[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

[h1]PC Port Quality[/h1]

The HUD while playing is fine, but all of the menus have an abundance of issues. They look slick, but elements break apart and hidden elements are shown when scaled wider than 16:9. The menus support keyboard/mouse/controller, but it seems like a mashup of shortcuts that work well on some and not on others. It’s really quite a mess beyond the first glance, and while none of this effects the gameplay, it does cause resetting the level to be a pain depending on your input method. A Keyboard-only level reset takes 13 inputs... There's plenty of room for a reset key; it would alleviate a ton of the frustration during the more difficult stages.

Key rebinding is present but isn’t complete, and controller is limited to one default mapping which I don’t find to be all that optimal. I opted for the keyboard for all of my play at the end of the game, as the default mapping played well, and was the most responsive considering the movement is digital rather than analog. Local Co-op is playable with a a single keyboard and/or controllers. Co-op keyboard defaults make little sense, but can be rebound separately from the singleplayer controls.

The game supports at least 144hz and forces v-sync. However, the camera and walking enemies update position matching the refresh, while the bouncing enemies update around 60hz and will appear to stutter.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

The core gameplay across all modes entails walking along the floor, dashing, and firing directly upwards, as bugs crawl out of every surface. It's similar to a traditional arcade shooter (Galaga / Space Invaders) but the dash and variety of enemy movements/attacks make it quite unique. Each bug is color-coded, contrasting strongly with the background environments. This is key as their movement, attack, and self-replication patterns are consistent; reading them becomes essential when trying to perfect a level. None of the bugs actively seek you out in any way; you position yourself to avoid collisions and line up attacks. You can use your dash to put yourself in the way of danger to kill faster; you’re rewarded for that risk. Dashing won’t trigger while holding the fire button, so you can’t be sloppy with your inputs.

The main single-player mode consists of 30 levels across 5 areas, each with score targets for 1-3 star ratings and a target combo, achieved by killing bugs in succession before the 4 (6 w/ perk) second timer ticks down and without getting hit. The difficulty options simply adjust your maximum health, allowing you to take 1, 4, or 8 hits before death. You can survive through the 30 levels pretty quickly without too much trouble, but he challenge is meeting the score and combo-count requirements for each stage. While the difficulty setting has no impact on score, taking all of those hits and losing your combo each time will likely see you falling short of those goals. Losing the combo once in the middle of the stage could cut your final score by more than half, and leave your maximum combo under the target, as it’s usually seems tailored to 50-80% of the spawned bugs.

All of the bug spawns are orchestrated; you can memorize the patterns and will likely need to when perfecting the final few levels. I believe power-ups and weapons are dropped from specific enemies, but the actual item you get is randomized. There are coins to collect, and while they add slowly to your score, their intended use is buying upgrades to the weapons and power-ups, as well as 3 perks. Again, because of the score-attack focus, I don’t see why there is any progression system at all, though you’ll have the money for every unlock before you finish a single run through. It becomes irrelevant before you go back to complete all the score and combo targets. A better use for the coins in my mind would have been costumes for the player character; still something to unlock and look forward to, without putting you at an immediate disadvantage.

Panic, the only other mode at the moment, is an endless score attack and is playable with one or two players locally on the 5 maps. Players can revive each-other by spamming the A button over their body during a small window after they’re downed. The coins here are accumulated during the run, are reset upon death, and can be spent in the pause menu to enable all of the power-ups and passive buffs from the singleplayer. A deploy-able bubble shield is also added to the roster of power-ups. There are no achievements or unlocks tied to this mode, but kills during do contribute to the achievements, and it was good fun with a friend. A local VS mode was shown off a while back, but doesn’t exist in the current build.

Overall it's very tight and satisfying, but there will be certain moments where you feel cheated. I came across instances of glitches and inconsistencies that forced a reset. It’s all somewhat excusable, until it happens in the run you were nailing, ruining it and and frustrating the experience. Questionable choices involving components in the levels that can redirect enemies unexpectedly, bug out and block shots, or even kill you directly. Certain power-ups can also cause certain bugs to spaz out in unpredictable ways. It’s largely a fair and rewarding challenge, but when those conflicts can get to you. It's minor and only really appears in the end-game, but still something to be worked on.

[h1]Presentation[/h1]

A mix of Jetpack Joyride, Castle Crashers, and Awesomenauts, the visual aesthetic is exceptional. There’s a small amount of aliasing on some of the assets, but it’s largely crisp and defined, with excellent color choice. The bug designs, while nothing iconic, all have a goofy charm and wear bright colors that both assist in gameplay and look great. In hectic scenes, you’ll have many colors going at once, yet it remains unified because of the contrasting but not clashing color choices. The core sound effects are well defined, but the thumping electronic music was hit or miss for me.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

The Bug Butcher is a satisfying and unique 2D arcade shooter, where speed and precision are heavily rewarded. It’s charming, vibrant 2.5D cartoon aesthetic is very appealing but also helps keep hectic situations readable. While relatively light on content, it’s score attack format and achievements had me enjoying myself all the way to 100% completion in around 8 hours of play, with only a small amount of frustration perfecting the final few levels, stemming from small glitches or inconsistencies. The menu UI needs some work and though the port is nowhere near top-notch, it’s good enough to be enjoyable on ultra-wide and high refreshrate displays. Co-op functionality for the 30 main missions, additional modes in general, and small enhancements like visual character customization would be greatly appreciated if development continues. In it’s current form it’s a good value and is well worth a look.

20973087.review:
[b] Key provided by developer [/b]

[h1] The bug butcher
Developer: Awfully nice studios
Publisher: Awfully nice studios
[/h1]


[b] Its butchering time [/b]


The bug butcher is a wave based fast paced shoot ‘em ‘up
I recommend a controller i felt like it played better.
If you hold the button you will fire constantly i recommend to you to do it unless you got a special weapon.
You are a bug butcher who's trying to clear out a base.
But if you don't kill all enemies in time you die
Along you you got yourself a scientist which only you really need to save from spiders or else game over, Plus he will drop crates for you which have weapons like the laser beam, Rocket launcher, and two more.
There's a dash which is quite important you can spam it if you like but you won't be invincible if you use it.
And then you also have special abilities like freezing, invincibility and more (shot)speed.
The patterns of the enemies are quite simple either they bounce, shoot or just fly around they will be quite easy to learn.
At some point they also introduce walls and platforms they can get quite annoying especially in the last chapter.
And that is the main gameplay now unto the modes and such things.
You have three modes Campaign ( 30 levels ) which i found to be quite easy.
Then there's panic which is just a random wave mode which after a wave you can buy upgrades, and it's probably the place with most replayability next to the achievements.
There's also co-op which is just panic mode but with co-op [strike] If you have any irl friends [/strike] But it's local only.
In the campaign you also have upgrades they are pretty basic weapon upgrades and abilities upgrades, but you also have these suit modifications like a shield i didn't really use them cause i didn't see the need for them
The campaign is pretty short it took me like 1.6 hours ( Note i lost my save at some point for buggy reasons so that's why i have more than 4 hours atm)
The difficulty however it doesn't change much it only changes the amount of health you have, like in hard you only have 1 health which is insta death on hit.


Visually the game looks pretty good the enemy designs are great, Though most enemies are blobs.
Character designs are nice aswell.
The ui however is awkward with a controller.
The sounds and music are all good but it's quite jarring to me when you die the music resets.
The other sounds are solid as well not much to say about them really
And story wise there's nothing most dialogue is just explaining mechanics.
I did run into one bug which wiped my save which sucked.


So overall it's a good shoot em up with a good variety of enemies and a good soundtrack.
But with a short campaign but you'll probably spending most time in panic mode.
It comes with it flaw however the ui is just awkward.
Plus if you really are not sure to buy this go try the demo.



[i]No drama, [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/justreviews]Just Reviews.[/url][/i]

20971392.review:
[h1]Review For The Bug Butcher[/h1]
Review by: [url=steamcommunity.com/id/dehu92]DEHU[/url]

[h1]Pros :[/h1]
- Cartoonish Graphics
- Smooth Controls
- Very Enjoyable Gameplay
- Fitting music

[h1]Cons :[/h1]
- 3 Health is too little in Panic.

[h1]Review :[/h1]
The Bug Butcher is a really fun shooter.

[h1]Gameplay :[/h1]
You play as a bug killer of some sort to kill some special alien bugs that have invaded the facility and you have to kill them all.
There is a catch though. You have a time limit for each stage, from 2-3 minutes and if you haven't killed the aliens before the timer
runs out you lose.
There are also scientists that if killed you lose. Only Spiders can kill them though.
There are a powerup that can freeze the timer and enemies, called a Freeze Grenade.

You have a Machine gun as standard weapon, but you can find pickup weapons on the ground that randomly spawns.
You also have powerups you can use after you have charged your powerup meter by killing the bugs.

You can run from side to side and dash.
You only shoot vertical upwards.

Sometimes tactics are a good thing to have, like if you have a Freeze Grenade or Homing Missiles,
use it while there are tons of enemies on the screen or if you need to buy more time.

There are 30 stages split up in 5 maps. Each time you change map you are in an elevator and you face enemies on your way up.
There are new enemies in the elevator so you have some knowledge about what you can face in the next map.

There are lots of different types of bugs like; small fireball bugs, Huge bugs that splits to smaller bugs when killed,
some kills you in one hit if the land on your head, ect.
The game is so much fun, the controls are smooth and the music fits so well to the game.

I think there is a tiny bug, when you choose any of the game modes that it shows the controller buttons on the upgrade menu, insted of keyboard keys

The game would fit as a Mobile/Tablet game too due to the simple gameplay and controls.

[h1]Game Modes: [/h1]
Arcade is the story mode of the game, with 30 stages split into 5 maps.
Panic is Survival. Survive 3 mins or until death in one of 5 maps.
Panic Co-op is Co-op Survival. Same rules, Survive 3 mins or until death in one of 5 maps.
There are shops after wave 1 and every two rounds afterwards.

[h1]Weapons: [/h1]
Machine Gun is your standard weapon.
Laser Beam is a beam that kills the bugs with one hit.
Rocket Launcher shoots spread fire missiles.
Gatling Gun is a fast shooting gun.
Lightning Gun deals chain damage to bugs near the bug hit by the shot.

[h1]Powerups: [/h1]
Speed Injection boosts your attack speed for a limited time depending on level of upgrade.
Freeze Grenade Freezes Both Bugs and the timer for a limit time depending on level of upgrade.
Homing Missiles shoots Homing Missiles at the bugs and the amount of missiles depends on level of upgrade.

[h1]Perks: [/h1]
Speed Booster makes you move 30% faster.
Bug Shield gives you a shield protected against 1 hit and doesn't break combo on hit.
Combo Booster makes the combo last 6 seconds insted of 4 seconds.

[h1]Pickups: [/h1]
Double Damage are fire shots that deals double damage.
Bullet Storm makes you shoot twice as fast.
Heart give you 1 health
Time Watch gives you more time (Only in Panic)

[h1]Additional Infomation :[/h1]
Developer: Awfully Nice Studios 
Publisher: Awfully Nice Studios 
Genre: Singleplayer, Co-op, Shoot 'Em Up, Action, Indie
Released on Steam: 19. jan 2016

[h1]Follow my Curator page :[/h1][url=store.steampowered.com/curator/6858371/]http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6858371/[/url]
[h1]This review is written for :[/h1][url=steamcommunity.com/groups/PandasCorner]The Panda's Corner[/url]

20968426.review:
Die Parallelen zu dem SNES Klassiker "Super Pang" bzw "Pang" sind nicht von der Hand zu weisen. Ihr sitzt in einem Raum mit springenden Aliens fest und könnt nur nach oben schiessen. Was sich erstmal komisch anhört wird ganz schnell sehr sucht erzeugend.
Ihr habt neben eurer Waffe auch Power Ups zur Hilfe mit denen sich die Horden von Gegnern beseitigen lassen. Das Belohnungzentrum eures Hirn wird auch dauer befeuert, da es nach fast jedem Level ein neues Power Up freigeschaltet wird. Mit den Münzen die ihr im Level einsammelt könnt ihr euch aber natürlich auch selbst upgraden. Sei es einen Schild der euer Leben und das Kombometer schützt oder euch schneller macht.
Wie im Klassiker könnt ihr euch auch einen Freud zur Seite holen und dann gemeinsam die Forschungseinrichtung von Ungeziefer befreien.
Die Grafik ist im Comic 2D Look von etwa Castle Crasher und Battle Block Theater gehalten, und birgt allerlei feine Details.
Falls ihr könnt solltet ihr aber mit einem Controller spielen, da man so den Dash besser nutzen kann.

The Bug Butcher, the great new game from Awfully Nice Studios.
This game reminds me of old times, "Bubble Trouble", anyone remember?

The game has a simple concept, shoot enemies from below. The game is addicting, in a good way. It can make you play for hours, time flies by.
The Singleplayer is short, but stays the same. I recommend playing it either on Medium or Hard, which is pretty decent to play. Panic Mode is awesome, waves and waves of enemies, trying to kill you. Getting harder every wave, more and more to dodge. Co-Op is the last gamemode, which I didn't try yet. - Good old times
- Simple but fun concept
- Positively Addicting
- Co-op
- Upgrade System

[b]Cons[/b]
- Co-op only 2 players

[b]Rating[/b]
8.5/10
It's simple, small and reminds me of good old times. Addicting and fun for hours.

[b]Recommended?[/b]
Yes, I highly recommend it. For this price you've got a new fun game, which will be fun for hours and hours. Even with the Leaderboards, you can always show off to your friends. Try playing it with a friend together, it would be even more fun then!
Very well done and a big thumbs-up for the developers of this great game!

20837462.review:
Análise completa em http://www.poepra2.com.br/analise/the-bug-butcher/

---

Quem é das antigas já deve ter ouvido falar no clássico shooter arcadesco Super Pang/Super Buster Bros, não? Resumindo a ideia, um jogo de plataforma, onde você anda só para os dois lados e atira para cima.

Parece fácil ou desinteressante? Que nada! A ideia é basicamente essa sobre sua mecânica: simples de entender, porém difícil de se dominar. E acima de tudo, extremamente divertida e intensa.

Trazendo dois modos de jogo, e a opção de cooperativo para 2 jogadores locais num deles, The Bug Butcher é um belíssimo sucessor espiritual, ressuscitando a simplicidade de um jogo antigo numa belíssima execução artística.

Você assumirá o papel de Harry, um famoso exterminador mais conhecido pela alcunha de o açougueiro, que é chamado para livrar um laboratório de pesquisa de uma terrível infestação de insetos.

A campanha do jogo, bem curtinha, é chamada de modo Arcade, onde o jogador enfrentará 30 missões em sequência, divididas em 5 mapas diferentes. A sexta missão de cada mapa se passa num elevador, que dá acesso ao próximo mapa.

A história é praticamente inexistente, com um pequeno tutorial de começo que irá ensinar o básico do jogo, introduzir o anti-herói e o contexto em que o jogo se passa.

No modo Arcade existem progressões permanentes: a cada fase, o jogador acumulará moedas, seja matando inimigos e coletando-as, ou cumprindo as 4 metas de cada fase para receber um dinheiro adicional. Com esse dinheiro, será possível comprar armas, powerups e perks. Cada arma e powerup possui uma fase mínima para ser destrancado, e também permitirão que se gaste dinheiro adicional para melhorá-los.

Já o modo Panic, não há nenhuma progressão permanente. É basicamente um modo survival, onde o jogador deverá aguentar o máximo de tempo vivo. Você ainda acumulará moedas durante a partida, e poderá sim comprar armas, powerups e perks da mesma forma. Porém, ao final da partida, tudo vai embora, como em um jogo roguelike.

Em ambos os modos de jogo, sua pontuação da fase será salva, e o jogo automaticamente irá te colocar no placar global. O jogo também automaticamente irá colocar sua pontuação contra a de seus amigos, incitando assim uma boa competição amigável.

O jogo conta com 5 armas, sendo uma acessível o tempo todo, e o restante delas temporárias, necessitando de serem pegas nas fases para serem usadas, e tendo munição limitada para limitar o seu uso num intervalo de tempo.

Os powerups são poderosas habilidades ativas, que exigem que a barra de powerup seja carregada antes de usá-los. Caso você possua múltiplos powerups liberados, o jogo fará uma rotação a cada uso, sendo impossível escolher usar o que se quer.

Por fim, Perks são habilidades passivas que melhorarão a eficiência do personagem como um todo. Você poderá ter todas, mas só uma delas poderá ficar ativa por vez no modo Arcade.

Apesar de ser um jogo de plataforma, tanto a mobilidade do personagem quanto o combate são bem diferentes do usual. Pra começar, você só deslocará para esquerda e direita, utilizando as teclas A e D. Para aumentar a mobilidade temporariamente, você poderá segurar a tecla CTRL, que fará o personagem deslizar rapidamente, gastando sua barra de estamina, que se recupera bem rápido.

O layout das fases também costuma ser bem simples: uma tela limitada, onde você passará todo o tempo da fase nela. Os inimigos surgem em levas, com um indicador visual de onde vão aparecer.

Algumas fases possuem recursos únicos em seu layout: barreiras verticais que irão limitar a movimentação dos inimigos e a sua, ou barreiras horizontais que irão atrapalhar seus tiros e interferir na movimentação inimiga, chamadas móveis nas paredes, ou mesmo um mecanismo que poderá te esmagar toda hora.

E como faz para atirar? Oras, a tecla SHIFT. Com um pequeno detalhe: você atirará para cima, em linha reta. Obrigatoriamente. Dessa forma, você deverá ficar abaixo dos inimigos para atirar neles. O desafio portanto é reconhecer os padrões de movimentação e ataque dos inimigos, se posicionar bem, e mandar bala.

Ao matar vários inimigos, você encherá sua barra de Powerup, que poderá ser usado com a tecla Espaço. Os efeitos de Powerups costumam ser muito fortes, mas duram bem pouco.

Os gráficos do jogo são muito belos: apesar de ser um 2D um tanto cartunesco, todos os personagens são desenhados a mão, e compensam em riqueza nas animações. O grande destaque visual do jogo fica certamente por conta das animações de morte: dependendo da forma que você morre, é uma animação diferente que acontece!

A interface nas partidas é bem limpa e espaçada, fornecendo um bom indicador de tudo que você precisa saber, sem atrapalhar nem um pouco. Infelizmente, cometeram um sério deslize nos menus do jogo, que parecem ser otimizados para touch em sua maioria, e somado à falta de opções gráficas, fazem o jogo perder pontos pelo desleixo.

Outra surpresa no jogo é sua trilha sonora, de nível profissional: ao todo são 10 músicas, que casam bem com a ambientação futurista do jogo, e contribuem para o clima psicodélico, e ainda por cima, auxiliam na concentração!

Os sons são curtos e simples em sua maioria, ficando como fundo em relação à trilha sonora. A única exceção talvez sejam as vozes dos personagens, que são engraçadas e sem forma definida. O resultado é um todo bem harmônico, extremamente agradável, divertido e nada cansativo.

Embora não haja campanha cooperativa, é possível jogar o modo Panic em dois jogadores locais. Naturalmente, não há drop-in, o que não prejudica nada, pelo fato das partidas serem curtas e a pontuação separada. O dinheiro ganho, a pontuação e os upgrades são os mesmos para ambos os jogadores.

A dinâmica do jogo é praticamente a mesma, exceto que quando um jogador morre, o outro jogador pode revivê-lo. E caso um dos jogadores morra e não seja revivido a tempo, a fase será perdida.

Vou ser sincero: eu nunca joguei o Super Pang/Super Buster Bros, clássico em que este jogo se baseia, e certamente fiquei com um preconceito de sua simplicidade a princípio, especialmente por adorar mecânica complexas...

Porém, o jogo rapidamente me conquistou, pela sua velocidade e intensidade, que me dava uma dose de adrenalina constante, e ao mesmo tempo, o excesso de padrões nas mecânicas dos inimigos, que me fazia analisar tudo como um quebra-cabeça vivo.

As fases são curtinhas, então todo esse envolvimento que o jogo demanda não cansa. E claro, ver que a cada fase você melhora, ao ponto de subir na leaderboard gradativamente ao repetir uma mesma fase, é extremamente recompensador!

Não posso deixar de novamente elogiar a arte no jogo, que tanto visualmente quanto sonoramente, estimulam mais ainda a jogatina. Até morrer fica divertido, com tanta animação diferente (e bem feita) nas mortes!

20762587.review:
I was interested to see somebody give super buster bros. another shot.  I have to say, this game's art and animation are very well done and in general it has a lot of polish.  I was happy to see that it had co-op and played with a friend which was a major selling point for me.  

I had about 30 minutes of fun in co-op but the fun dried up quickly.  Mainly because I found the upgrade system to be not very well thought out.  The choices are not very strategic since the weapons drop at random, and the more upgrades you buy the less you know what will drop.  You cannot buy more then one shield (you should be able to but with increased cost) and some of the upgrades are confusing like the "extra health".  

Also, why can't you play the normal levels 2 player?  I really think that would have given the co-op a lot more staying power.  Overall I say if you watch the trailer and it looks cool, go for it as long as you are not buying it for the co-op.  It's a very nicely polished game and a lot of people haven't played buster bros, so it's good we have a solid example out there to cary the torch.

20682856.review:
[b][i]The Bug Butcher[/i] is a fun little arcade shooter best played in local couch co-op.[/b] This title is polished and plays very smoothly, with responsive controls. I say 'little' because while the content that is present is certainly fun, there is little complexity or depth. Leveling up weapons is fairly limited, and there are not a large variety of them, either. The music and artwork are pretty good, to boot.

[b]Pros:[/b]
+The price-point is definately appropriate. Good replay value, even if there are not metric tons of levels and content.
+Tight controls. Controller support is good.
+Lots of fun to be had in local couch-coop.
+Artwork and music are appropriate, and well done.

[b]Cons:[/b]
-Could benefit from an increase in complexity and variety of weapons and levels.

[b]Try the demo. You'll know right away if this is your thang or not.[/b]

20643964.review:
[u] Summary: [/u]
Even in this time of indie games reviving game genres of old, the Pang genre hasn't exactly gotten a plethora of games. The Bug Butcher however does the genre proud, with its twitch gameplay doing its best to bring out the strengths of the genre. Great visuals complement action that forces you to keep shooting and killing, but being smart about it and not being reckless. While the game could use a little bit more variety for the long haul, what's there is extremely polished. Great performance plus loading times that are practically non-existent help in getting you right back in the action and keeping you there. It's a genre that gets to the basics, and The Bug Butcher is no exception to that. But small smart decisions regarding the gameplay helps make a game that kept me entertained throughout me playing it, and well worth the price point in question. Definitely a worthy successor in the genre, updated for the new age. 

[b]  Video Review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0-8_5-Suh28[/b]

[u] Lists: [/u]
[b]+:[/b]
[list]
[*] Tight twitch gameplay that keeps the action going. Takes me back to the old arcade days. 
[*] Solid controls that give you the right amount of control, and can allow you to be reckless and deal damage to yourself. That may sound weird to say, but part of the appeal of these games is the twitch gameplay, and consequences.
[*] Strong aesthetic that complements gameplay. Great use of color choice to make action clear for the player.
[*] Great performance, and minimal load times. How an arcade game should play.
[*] Like the gravity mechanics with enemies and hitting them with your gun. It increases the skill ceiling especially with the combo multiplier. 
[*] Honestly, the game is probably under priced, even at it's full price. Feel like for the experience, you get your money's worth and then some. 
[/list]

[b]-:[/b]
[list]
[*] Do wish there was a little bit more variety in the long run. A couple more weapons, levels, and enemy types would have done wonders.
[*] Feel like the upgrade system doesn't really do much other then add a bulletpoint feature to the game. Very basic. 
[*] I really can't put my finger on it, but something feels missing with the sound design. I didn't see a real difference in gameplay when turning the sound off, which is unusual for games like this. But I can't say WHAT is missing. 
[/list]

20629628.review:
I want to start this review off by letting everyone know that I am by no means a professional reviewer, i'm just someone who really loves games, and I like to play indie gems from time to time.

Alright so going into this games I kept my expectations in check due to being burnt by other games in the past, but I figured for $8 why not? But to my great pleasure this game is FANTASTIC.

Graphically the game looks handrawn reminds me of games like Critter Crunch with the 2D art work, the bugs splatter, the blaster/power up effects look good, and the bugs themselves look really good for what it all is.

Gameplay wise it's fairly simple but challenging, the bugs bounce up and down across the screen and you're character runs across the same screen only allowed to vertically (up), now on paper this sounds fairly boring and standard, but when you consider other elements like; creatures breaking into smaller variations of themselves, some creatures shooting little beams that could hurt you, stage hazards and more, it adds variety and challenge to the gameplay all while you're trying to keep a combo meter and your high score rising in order to reach individual goals in each level.

It seems pretty simple but as i went on and was pushed to increase my combos and score I found myself becoming more agile and offensive in my appoarch against these bugs, as opposed to waiting for them to bounce and go on killing them, more often than not i would rush them before they even hit the ground once.

The audio in the solid as expected, the musical score isn't anything too blaring or annoying, and usually i'm too focused on keeping my combos up to really care about the music.

Finally the replayablity in this game is actually quite excellent, mroe often than not I found myself repeating levels to hit each of the goals with in the levels, and even switching to a harder mode to challenge myself...I failed to mention this earlier but I actually enjoy how the harder mode mixes up the enemy spawns as opposed to just being the same as the lower modes with more enemies.

All in all, I love this game, the moment I played the demo, closed it out, and kept coming back to it over and over again, I knew I had to buy it, I reccomend that you do the same :)

19656948.review:
I held off recommending this game until the addition of local co-op Panic Mode was released. 
On its own, single player mode is solid and provides some chaotic moments but overall it lacks the polish and replay value that other contenders in the same arena can offer (ahem, Assault Android Cactus).

However the cooperative local player is where this title truly shines and reveals some of the most frenetic fights for survival you can find. You'll battle nerves, frustration and bloodshot eyes as the luxury of blinking goes out the window. 

The inability to map custom buttons is a real drawback and the menus (all of them) are atrocities to convention and miserable to navigate. Thankfully you won't spend too much time in them, and overall it's not exactly  a deal breaker since they're most likely working on bigger problems atm.  


+ 6.5/10
+ Grab a friend to truly unleash the games potential.
+ Good Xbox 360 controller support.
+ Decent powerups provide enough variety with which to dispatch the vermin. 
+ Well designed enemy mechanics.

- Lack of button mapping is a drawback (put that dash button on RT guys!)
- 2-player panic mode has a UI flaw that lets the player restart the game without a confirmation.
 ***You don't know how badly this needs to be fixed asap. Better to map the option to one of the start buttons all together.***
-The main title screen is drab and could potentially lower expectations from players from the get-go as an unfinished and cheap title. 

Fix these flaws and spice up the level design/art and you've easily got an 8/10 game on your hands.

18797891.review:
Actuellement en accès anticipé; il m'a fallu environ 2h30 pour finir le seul mode disponible pour le moment à savoir le mode arcade composé de 30 niveaux, en difficulté moyenne. La difficulté n'influence que sur le nombre de vie dont on dispose (8 en facile, 4 en moyen et 1 une difficile).
A la fin de chaque niveau vous avez un tableau de score montrant le nombre d'étoiles obtenues, votre place dans le classement mondial ou par rapport à vos amis. Idéal pour ceux qui aiment le scoring. Si vous souhaitez terminer le jeu avec toutes les étoiles et tout les bonus de combo, il vous faudra de nombreuses tentatives et la durée de jeu se verra donc allongée de manière non-négligeable à mon avis.

La prise en main est immédiate, il ne faut en effet que 5 touches pour effectuer les différentes actions : aller à gauche, à droite, dasher, tirer et utiliser les powers-up.
Le joueur possède une arme de base mais 5 autres peuvent être récupérées de façon aléatoire dans les niveaux à la mort des ennemis (avec une utilisation limitée) ainsi que 3 powers-up aléatoires qui s'obtiennent en infligeant des dégâts. Trois perks sont également disponibles, il suffit juste de les acheter avec l'argent que l'on récupère au sol et en finnisant les niveaux. Un seul perk peut être équipé à la fois.

Les graphismes sont mignons et de qualité, les arrière-plans sont également bien travaillés et ont leurs identités propres. 
Le bestiaire est varié bien que certains monstres se ressemblent dans leur comportement. 
Les différents décors amènent avec eux des éléments de jeu différents comme des plateformes, des barrières, des élements dangereux (flammes, presse) qui peuvent parfois vous gêner ou au contraire vous aider si vous savez les utiliser correctement.

Le jeu peut se jouer au clavier ou à la manette.

Le jeu n'est pas en français mais les quelques dialogues ne sont pas difficiles à comprendre et au pire, ne pas les comprendre n'empêche clairement pas de s'amuser.

Une démo est également disponible si vous souhaitez vous faire un avis sur ce jeu.

18636682.review:
Минуты, посвященные  игре, доставили большое удовольствие и теперь мне хочется говорить о ней только в превосходной степени.

The Bug Butcher обладает великолепным визуальным оформлением, отличным музыкальным сопровождением и увлекательным игровым процессом, к-рый порой слишком уж сложен, но весьма азартен. 

Сдержанный юмор, едва заметные отсылки к серии игр Half-Life, яркая жизнерадостная палитра, высокий уровень всех без исключения составляющих данного продукта не оставляют мне сомнений в том, что вы будете удовлетворены своим приобретением.

Лаариса, супруга:
"Режим совместной игры произвел на меня хорошее впечатление. Оч. понравилось вместе с партнером уничтожать разнокалиберных, забавных монстров. Сложность нарастает постепенно и это делает процесс еще интереснее. Все выглядит мило. Заставляют улыбнуться те звуки, к-рые издают персонажи игры - особенно крик ученого, схваченного пауком.  С удовольствием буду играть в это снова, снова  и снова!".

18488823.review:
EDIT: El mejor juego Indie al que puedes sacar partida. Vicioso y de elevadas dificultades de niveles conforme progresas.

[h1]Simpático y con muchos bugs por acabar...[/h1]

No esperaba que mis expectativas sobre este juego fueran demasiado buenas, y es que, The Big Butcher, es uno de los mejores [b]Early Access[/b] que he probado (por ahora) de lo que le resta del año. El juego en sí no tiene una historia, pero sí una serie de niveles en las que tendrás que matar a diferentes «bichos» de todos los colores en unas salas espaciales con tu Machine Gun, pero antes de entregarnos a la muerte de estos bichos, podemos pasar un pequeñito y casi nulo tutorial en la que se nos presentará el juego fuera del planeta Tierra y en la que nuestro protagonista desciende de su nave espacial y aterriza en la base en la que se encuentra instalado.

No es un juego complicado, por lo mucho puedes hacerte bolas con los controles (sí, debo mencionar aquí que el juego no está traducido al español) y que sus mecánicas son muy similares a cualquier juego de disparos. Puede que te traiga en tu banco de tu memoria [b]Metal Slug[/b], puesto que es más o menos así el juego: disparar a tus enemigos y avanzar horizontalmente dentro de un escenario, en este caso, en un tipo de bunker en la que salen los bichos por doquier. Y en la que podemos ganar moneditas para poder potenciar los ataques de nuestras armas en todo momento, ¿qué padre, no? Sin embargo, al ser un Acceso Anticipado se te bloquean muchas cosas. Hay como un tipo de niveles que no se encuentran abierto al público en general. Lástima, tendrás que conformarte con el desbloqueo de niveles conformes avances, pero sólo hasta ahí.

En el aspecto gráfico es algo que maravillará a muchos, pues su estilo visual es muy hermoso que me hacen estar jugando un tipo de comic (aunque no es el caso) lo digo por el tipo de tonalidades que tiene el propio juego. Cuando pruebas el tutorial puedes notar como la tempestad de la nieve es sumamente impresionante. Ojalá pudiera matar a los bugs ahí a fuera...

Por último, el sonido, ¡quiero la BSO! Son bastantes buenos los tracks que tienen de fondo, no dudo que en un futuro muy cercano pongan a disposición del público el soundtrack del juego, ya que los sonidos muy «electrónicos» se ajustan perfecto para este tipo de juegos. Y pues en general, los efectos de los sonidos son muy amigables al igual que las voces chistosas de nuestro protagonista y su amigo el «minion» de traje blanco espacial.

Para concluir, vale la pena echarle una probada el juego, ¿he mencionado que tiene una opción en la que puedes checar tu score con otros jugadores a nivel mundial? Cuando finalizas un nivel ganas puntos y cuantos más puntos ganes; mayor será tu calificación y en la que se te pondrá en un pedestal con otros jugadores. Si lo tuyo son los retos y quieres superar a los 10 primeros jugadores con la mejor calificación de The Bug Butcher, valdrá la pena que lo compres.

[i]9.2[/i]

Alienígenas que invaden naves espaciales y acaban con tripulaciones enteras. Otros que tratan de invadir la tierra, o incluso destruirla. ¿Pero qué pasa cuando se convierten en una auténtica plaga? Hay que llamar a un exterminador experimentado para que nos libre del problema.

Su misión (la nuestra en realidad) es limpiar un laboratorio especial en el planeta Zoit que se ha llenado de toda clase de alienigenas, a cual más peligroso y molesto que el anterior.

The Bug Butcher is a cool spin on the classic Pang genre with new school upgrades and boss monsters.

The game is currently in early access where i finished it in around 5 hours but for a good player they could do it much quicker. Hopefully with the full release they add more content as it is a highly addictive game which i completed in just a few sittings but left wanting for more still worth the price of admission if you loved the classic games of the genre.

The content after you finish the 30 missions is just going back to set global high scores which could be quite addictive but very much for the perfectionist. Im just hoping they add another 20 or so missions to flesh the game out.

Im gonna leave this short review here until it goes to full release where i will update it with a full fleshed review.

Even for early access it is well worth owning and playing id give my big thumbs up

18290813.review:
[h1]
☛Что вы ожидаете когда заходите в «обзоры» какой либо игры?
✔ Как автор описывает красоту графики?
✔ Что в нем расхвалят детальность проработки игры?
✔ Распишут полноту возможностей самой игры?

Но вскоре начнется новая эпоха обзоров! Когда вас их просят написать, чтобы повысить ваш шанс выиграть новую игру!
Так что господа, такие игры как:
✘Gunjitsu ✘TeraBlaster ✘Jet Racing Extreme ✘Commander Cool 2 и ✘The Bug Butcher 
вскоре будут перстить копипастами или просто парой строк, дабы получить новую халяву на том же сайте где их раздавали! Я к слову не первый, европейские обзоры уже завалены подобным…но и не последний)) Выиграть то хочется!

И все же The Bug Butcher представляет из себя довольно красочный экшен-платформер, основная фишка которого это невозможность главного героя стрелять никуда кроме как наверх! Rappelant de vieux jeux flash - On se déplace horizontalement et on tire verticalement sur les ennemis qui se séparent en deux plus petits ennemis (un qui part à gauche et l’autre à droite).

C’est un bon challenge et demande une certaine coordination et observation (quelque chose que notre cerveau adore faire) et donc c’est très divertissant.

Remis au goût du jour avec des graphismes attrayants, une musique entrainante, plusieurs pouvoirs spéciaux et des améliorations à acheter avec l’argent récolté en jouant. Trois modes de difficultés pour s’adapter aux joueurs de différents niveaux, une multitude de monstres…

En bref c’est un jeu qui vaut la peine d’être joué si on veut (y) passer un bon moment (dans les deux sens du terme, parce que c'est distrayant mais  « Allez, j’essaie 10 minutes… » et 2 heures passent).

18198247.review:
It's really hard to recommend this game. There are external problems and minor annoyances (menu isn't that user friendly with a controller) that would prevent me from recommending this game. However looking past these problems and only considering the quality of the game itself (in particular the graphics and the gameplay), I can do nothing else than recommend this game.

It's a very beautiful game, it runs smooth and the animations are great. I haven't had any performance isssues and it runs at a smooth 60 fps. The core gameplay is very solid. It's a vertical shooter where you have to defeat wave of increasingly harder (and different) enemies. It's easy to get in a great flow and there is enough of a challenge to keep you entertained.

So why is it really hard to recommend this game? The developers say the game has 30 levels (although only 18 are available in Early Access) and though it's technically accurate, it isn't really true. The real levels are called floors, of which there are only five. This results in very repetitive environments. The things the developer calls levels is just increasing the number of enemies (or adding another type) after a series of waves (four or five waves per level). This means there is a severe lack in content. In Early Access this is even worse.

A lack of content doesn't have to be a bad thing (if the quality is good, which is the case), but the game has to be priced accordingly. This however isn't the case. The price of the game is way too high. The developer even says they plan to increase the price of the game after Early Access. This would be a grave mistake. Even with the planned features it simply isn't worth € 9,99, not even by a long shot. This is a game that shouldn't be priced above € 4,99. I wouldn't even consider buying the game at € 9,99. If by mistake I did buy it, I would have asked for a refund based on the lack of content. I don't think I'm alone in this and the developers should really consider this. It would be a real shame this game would fail, because the developer didn't understand the value of the game. It shouldn't fail based on quality, but it will fail if the price isn't lowered. 

TLDR: 

- Should you buy the game in Early Access: No
- Should you buy the game for € 9,99: No
- Is the game worth playing: Yes
- Should you buy the game if has a lower price (€4,99 or below): Yes

FULL DISCLOSURE: I have recieved this game for free from the developer.

18179350.review:
The bug butcher es un juego arcade tipo "Pang!", el clasico juego de romper burbujas (en este caso bichos) con un nuevo lavado de cara.

Cuando escribo esto el juego aun esta en early, pero la verdad es que ya es totalmente jugable, (aunque solo tiene modo historia por ahora) y está bastante libre de bugs (JA!).

En cuanto a gráficos pues son bastante resultones, los bichos estan bien logrados así como los powerups, escenarios y personajes, en conjunto hacen un producto vistoso, llamativo pero sin ser un derroche gráfico (cosa que tampoco necesitaria).

En cuanto al gameplay es rápido, muy arcade, simple en sus teorias y desafiante si se desea exprimir al máximo, el objetivo del juego es simple, entrar en una zona, limpiarla de bichos lo mas rapido y mejor posible (dado que se le da mucha importancia a los combos) recoger monedas y mejorar nuestros perks y armas.

El juego es adictivo y rápido, ideal para partidas rápidas, aun no disfruta de multijugador cosa que tiene pinta de ser realmente divertida.

Yo conseguí una copia gratuita desde orlygift, pero no es mala compra si lo pillas por tremor o en algun bundle, personalmente no creo que valga los 10€ que piden por el, mas que nada por el tipo de juego. Aun así, si lograis pillarlo barato es muy recomendable.

PD: Buena banda sonora, acompaña bien al juego, los personajes son divertidos y utilizan mucho el humor en sus conversaciónes.

18142405.review:
Non seulement le jeu est beau mais il est en plus très bien animé. Le personnage répond parfaitement et le jeu a un dynamisme incroyable. Le fait de pouvoir dasher permet de passer rapidement d’un groupe d’ennemis à un autre pour boucler très rapidement les niveaux et obtenir des points bonus supplémentaires pour essayer de se hisser en haut du classement en ligne.

Les niveaux s’enchaînent très bien et une fois le jeu lancé, il est dur de s’arrêter… et c’est d’ailleurs actuellement son seul défaut, on boucle trop rapidement tout le contenu. La version finale apportera un monde supplémentaire, un mode deux joueurs (où vous devrez apparemment combattre votre ami) et un mode infini, mais pour le moment c’est un peu léger.

Les mondes sont par contre assez variés et apportent chacun une subtilité au gameplay de base. Les développeurs ont par ailleurs réussi à créer un bon nombre d’aliens aux comportements différents dont certains (les sortes d’araignées) vous ignorent pour s’attaquer directement aux scientifiques et vous obliger à venir les libérer très rapidement.

Je ne vais pas vous le cacher, j’attends maintenant avec impatience le contenu supplémentaire pour me jeter dessus. Le premier jeu d’Awfully Nice Studios est bien parti pour être une réussite totale !

Lire le test complet sur [url=http://www.gamesidestory.com/2015/09/21/preview-the-bug-butcher-pc-mac-linux/]Game Side Story[/url]

17952216.review:
Short Review: (more precise below):

+ Fun arcade shooter (nice "evolution" of Pang!)
+ Interesting pickups/weapons/activates
+ Fair (but hard) leveldesign
+ A highscore system (you care about)
+ Fast development progression!
+ Nice animations
+ Local Coop

- Only two mode 
- May be a bit fast/hard for some people AT FIRST
- A lot of "similar" enemies
- Still some bugs (but they get phewer and phewer each update).

More precise:

I have seen this game in Square Enix Collective 6 months ago, and there it looked like it had a lo of potential but there was just not much there (some death animations small number of enemies some weapon concepts)
Now 6 Months later there is quite a lot of content!
5 different Weapons! 
Lots of enemies (with good anymations),
Weapon/upgrade progression system
4*6 levels (with different mechanics)
Really good gameplay.

The game is hard, but rarely feels unfair. This speaks of a really good balancing!
The controls are smooth and easy.

Of course it still does not have too much content, but more content will come and replaying the levels (trying to get a beter highscore) really is fun!
Also getting more gold for a better high score in a level is also rewarding, it makes it feel more, like it does matter.

All in all the game IS allready good, but will most likely get even better (and longer)

17444646.review:
In The Bug Butcher you take on a role of Harry, a intergalactical mercenary bug exterminator who has been given a task on planet Zoit to deal with an bug infestation in a research compound. You must clear the research lab of bugs in order to keep the scientists working there safe.

Graphic design and visuals could be defined as grose and cute at the same time. All enemies you encounter are unique in terms of how they look and what they do, wrapped up in a cartoonish colorful look.

Before long you are freezing, bursting, frying and lasering hordes of strange-looking alien bug-beasts, and it feels so damn satisfying. Gameplay evolves around a static and unchanging environment where enemies dodge, crawl, fly, smash, bounce and even give birth to smaller versions of themselves. 

As you progress through the levels you will acquire more powerful weapons, upgrades and power-ups. You will also collect coins from bugs you slaughtered in order to upgrade your stats and equipment. 

Soundtrack is absolutely amazing and I wouldn’t be surprised if one day we get a soundtrack edition of the game.

The Bug Butcher is a fine example of a old-school style of gameplay with a lot of fun-factor involved. Although it lacks some verticality The Bug Butcher will make you spend hours on end progressing through the well designed and easy to look at lab slaughtering relentless hords of interesting and unique bug-like aliens.

[url=https://pcgamesnnews.wordpress.com/2015/08/08/preview-the-bug-butcher/]Full review[/url]

17241328.review:
Do you like fast, addicting and extremely challenging arcade shooters like we had in the 80's?  Then The Bug Butcher is definitely one to check out.  Currently available on Steam Early Access, The Bug Butcher is developed by the indie team at Awfully Nice Studios.

The Bug Butcher is a classic arcade style shoot up action game that challenges you to blow up bizarre alien bugs.  The developers have been putting a ton of work into the cartoon art style and terribly funny dialogue.

You first meet our hero as he arrives at a giant factory of sorts, where horrible alien space bugs have taken over the plant.  Running through the first few tutorial levels has you meet one of the factory workers, who appears to look a little like a talking Gameboy.  The dialogue and story are clever and funny, and the exposition provided by your guide is often scoffed about by the protagonist, due to it's completely satirical nature.

These first few moments set you up for the initial extremely addicting gameplay.  Dropping you through one room at a time, you must fire your gun upwards as the alien bugs drop from the ceiling and other areas, and bounce around the screen.  Each bug has unique skills and properties and you have to adapt to each as they fall from above.  Killing them earns you coins, and a score multiplier to rack up the points after each kill.  Every level has three to four waves of creatures before you can proceed to the next level, and of course, there is a time limit applied that you must beat.  As you are only able to shoot straight up, and can't jump, each shot has to be well timed as you avoid your bouncing enemies.

As the levels progress you're given a variety of powerups to use, that either increase your speed, power of your gun or give you temporary new weapons that cause mass destruction across the screen. These weapons can range from homing rockets, to a powerful laser that disintegrates everything, a gatling gun that fires at a high rate but needs to be charged, or a electric gun that on a successful hit jumps to other foes.  After enough kills you'll also gain a special attack with a variety of effects.  You can fire off more rockets, freeze everything on the screen, or even gain temporary invincibility and speed.  You'll need to use them all if you're going to survive the later levels.

Difficulty ramps up fast in The Bug Butcher.  Every level introduces new enemies.  Some are explained but others come out as a surprise and you'll have to quickly react to their new abilities and patterns.  At some points there are so many different foes on the screen it becomes almost impossible to survive as you try to dodge and take out the most dangerous enemies first.  Gameplay is broken up even more with elevator levels that take away some of your weapon drops, or other levels with various moving platforms or force fields that redirect your enemies bouncing and can either be a boon or a burden depending on what  you are dealing with at each moment.

The soundtrack keeps up with the action throughout, and gets your blood flowing.  The up beat electronic music really brings me back to my retro roots, and hours spent at the arcade, or in similar games on late consoles.  The music really keeps you on pace and meshes well with the chaos on the screen.

Throughout all these busy levels, the gameplay doesn't miss a beat.  I rarely saw my FPS drop below 60 regardless of how many enemies were on the screen.  It remained smooth and fast, aiding in the overly addictive nature of the game.  Frustrating death after frustrating death couldn't keep me from giving it one more go, or trying out the next level.  Each successful level rewards you with a star rating, and comparison to your steam friends and the overal rankings.  You'll also get new weapon drops as you go, as the game is really good at introducing something new with almost every level.

With competitive local multiplayer support planned, players are sure to have tense competitive battles with their friends shortly.  We can only hope that developer Awfully Nice Studios also has online multiplayer planned in a later update to really create a gem of fun gaming here.  

www.micbemac.com

"Don`t stop till you get enough!!" This Michael Jackson song came through my mind when i found out my wife and me had already been playing "the bug butcher" for more than total 26 hours. My first impression: "very nice graphics, cool sound and must be a simple game."

But wait: your enemies are getting more and more and stronger every level, there is a time limit and a limited number of lifes, you can "only" shoot veritcally  . ..  so you need the perfect timing, tactics and lots of coins (you earn them with an awesome combo feature) to upgrade your weapons and speed an skills from level to level . one mistake and you are dead - thats cruel - but for me the main fun ... you just cant stop playing before you killed this damn stage boss.... so you have to go through the whole level again and thats how you develop your skills until you are a real master ....    

i highly recommend this game to anyone who doesnt only like to play but likes to watch someone else playing - i had so much fun watching my wife die and die and die and die .. but she just couldnt stop playing. same for me...   so if you want to spend some fun hours playing a classic 2d side game this is the perfect game for you !

17178573.review:
Charming? Check. Addictive? Check. Funny? Check. Soundtrack? Checkmate. The Bug Butcher in a nutshell? Amazing. 

The Bug Butcher is a action shooter from Awfully Nice Studios. Currently, in Early Access on Steam for $7.99 (on sale from it's launch price of $9.99). Just having finished my first look of the game I have to say It's been awesome.

You see I've been following The Bug Butcher since around February when I found it had been Greenlit through Steam. While following on Facebook I was able to see this game developed over the last several months and with each animated enemy gif they posted I would get more and more interested. The art style alone is enough to want to give it a shot. 

https://youtu.be/FDTSpLUNP64?t=16m50s

On the surface it seems that The Bug Butcher is a stylized shoot 'em up. Where the enemies are a series of very well designed bug alien creature thingies (I imagine this whole thing takes place way in the future on the bug planet Klendathu but that's my fantasy). Your ultimate goal is to splatter their gooey insides all over this space station and save the day. 
You are fighting against the clock, leveling power ups, leveling perks, and frantically building your power up meter to beat the round. Trust me you'll need the power ups in the harder difficulties as you only have 1 health. As you finish each level you are awarded stars based on your final score, there are a possible 4 stars per level. You are also given coins, these coins are used to purchase upgrades to the aforementioned perks and power ups. The power ups are random and unlock at certain levels, the two I came across were rapid fire and freeze grenades. 

For an early access game The Bug Butcher is polished very well. All the animation, sound production, and gameplay is tight and well done. I didn't come across anything that stood out as "broken". It gets an A+ there. Having followed the development over the last few months I'm excited for the rest of the content, which includes a split-screen head to head multiplayer mode. From the looks of it, it reminds me of two player Bubble Bobble or Tetris, where you are both playing the same map simultaneously and as you do better it hurts your opponent. 

Overall, I think The Bug Butcher is a great early access title worth your time. It looks great, sounds great, and plays great. 
"The Only Good Bug, Is a Dead Bug!" (Starship Troopers)

For more Indie Games, Movies and Music check out EarlyAccessMedia.com, EarlyAccessPodcast.com and YouTube.com/EarlyAccessPodcast

17146713.review:
[h1]FINALLY ANOTHER ENTICING INDY TITLE WITH BEAUTIFUL GRAFX AND FRESH GAMEPLAY![/h1]

I just played the game for a bit over three hours straight until my fingers started to hurt. Let me say this: Normally I'm not a big fan of 2D platformers, but this title got me hooked from start to the last level of the current beta!

It has been a while since an early access indy title caught my attention. Last time it was "The Darkest Dungeon". In therms of level of polish this title reminds me a lot of the latter. But let's go into more detail:

THE PROS:
[list]
[*]Purely amazing grafics! I just LOVE the style of the characters, the enemies, their movement, the weapons, the FX. Let me tell you, there are AAA titles out there, which could learn a thing or two from this indy game... The first time I played "the darkest dungeon" was kind of similar in terms of grafics: You just don't expect THAT level of polish from an indy studio.
[*]Very interesting core loop: You can and will only shoot upwards and will have to calculate your movement and your weapon fire according to enemies movement. First it's pretty hard, but once you got the trajectories of the enemies mapped in your brain, the game starts getting addicitve! Also most of the enemies bounce a bit upwards, once you hit them. So after half an hour and after buying my first couple of upgrades I had the bugs basically dancing around my head without hurting me. - Very satisfying.
[*]The power-ups in this game only last for a couple of seconds. But oh boy, if you make those seconds count you will really feel like a pro-exterminator!
[*]The behaviour of the enemies is very well done and very well balanced. You have everything from lightning-spewing-firefly to big-ass-bug-birthing-blue-thing to scientist-eating-ceiling-crawler. Again I have to congratulate the devs to their top notch creativity and unique animation style.
[*]The upgrades are promising. You can feel the difference after every upgrade you buy. I even unlocked the +30% speed perk and let me tell you: The game plays completely different after that. Much more agressive.
[/list]

THE CONS:
[list]
[*]Even on "easy" the game is pretty hard! I've just seen a guy on twitch basically losing his nerves and nearly biting his constroller. The devs might need to work on the difficulty. Or they might just leave it as is. There are lot's of easy-to-play games out there.
[*]On my high-end computer (2x Gforce GTX980ti, win8.1) I get a lot of interface bugs, like stars not showing up or the score not being visible after a match. The score is there, it's just hidden. But since it's only launch day and this is an early access title anyways I think the devs will have this fixed pretty soon.
[*]The game is pretty short at the moment. After the first three areas it says "end of beta". Took me about 2 hours to play through on "easy". 
[*]You can play the game with the keyboard, but with a controler it's just much more fun.
[/list]

All in all I can [b]totally recommend this game[/b], even with it being an early access title. It's wonderfully crafted, has good game design, a lot of challenges. Go for it, especially at the launch-price of 7,99 euros it's worth your while. With that price it cost less than the last movie ticket I bought (for Ant-Man, LOL) and was way more fun than that movie ;-)

17142310.review:
The Bug Butcher starts off as a tribute to 1989 bubble-dividing arcade game Pang, but quickly mutates into a turbo-charged, explosive twitch blaster.

On the surface it's simple - run horizontally, shoot vertically and blast everything before the time runs down. Shoot a large alien and it divides into two medium ones, shoot THEM and they divide again into two small ones. If you fail to mop up the smaller aliens, you become overwhelmed. 

But as the game throws more types of alien at you, it becomes a game of tactics and timing. Can you dash under those five bouncing aliens to get to that crucial power-up? When do you set off the kill-everything homing missiles? Which alien is the priority kill?

Gameplay video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z_sJdW4x58I

Soon enough the aliens require your every reaction to deal with. There's a roof-crawling ant thing that blasts down a vertical pole of lightning for several seconds at a time. There's a leaping facehugger that means instant death. And one plant-like thing slowly sucks up your NPC friend in the background and, if you don't kill the plant in time it'll fail you the level. And so on.

The cartoon art is excellent and funny. The alien pests are full of bug-eyed charm, explosions feel satisfying and your hero Harry gets all the best lines.

The levels are scored in a very Angry Birds three-star system. You can progress just for completing the level, but getting just one star does hurt and you'll want to try again. The key to high scores is keeping a chain of kills (ie combos) going without being hurt. Some levels you'll unlock new weapons and power-ups. 

Every coin you collect on a completed level earns you coins that you can spend on permanently upgrading your character (weapon power, power-up strength, speed boost etc). Flipside, there's less incentive to keep plugging away for three-star ratings early on when you know your character can be much stronger after a few more levels. 

The levels are split into groups of six, each group taking place in one location in the research facility. Six feels like a lot - by the fifth, it feels a bit "this room AGAIN?!". But then the final level suddenly throws you into a confined elevator level, a kind of boss-style encounter where flames shoot from the walls. Each set of levels is sufficiently different, adding temporary barriers, platforms or a, er, kind of stompy thing. More levels and bosses are planned.

The game never feels unfair, even on hard mode where any contact with an alien is instant death. It's heart-pounding at times, with twitch reactions needed. The only real problem is that the core mechanic doesn't lend itself to huge variations in gameplay, no matter how many alien types are throw at you. It's best played for shorter sessions of score attack than trying to just plough through to the end as soon as possible (which, on easy, won't take too long).

This review is of the pre-release beta of the early access Steam version, with 18 out of a planned 30 levels implemented. Multiplayer is coming soon and should provide twice the laughs.

39508763.review:
XBOX Oneコントローラーを使用。

[u]宇宙の巨大な虫を退治する事がお仕事のキャラが主人公のステージクリア型横スク縦シューテング。各ステージはWaveごとに出現する敵を撃破していき、最終Waveの敵を全滅させればステージクリアとなる。クリア済みのステージは再度プレイが可能。[/u]

[h1][b]【良い点】[/b][/h1]

◆ 今作にはコンボの概念があり、コンボを続けながら敵を倒すことでスコアと敵撃破時に入手できるコインの量が増加していくので、高評価を狙うのがなかなかに面白い。高スコアを狙う場合は下記するアップグレードをいくつか入手してから挑戦するとやりやすい。

◆ 難易度は「Easy」「Medium」「Hard」の三つから選択でき、難易度毎に主人公のライフ等の最大値が「8」「4」「1」と減少し、倒されやすくなる。「Easy」モードのおかげで慣れてから高難易度に挑戦できるようになっているので、初心者の方にも優しい作りになっている。

◆　敵を倒したりステージをクリアした時に入手できるコインを使用することで主人公の強化が可能になっている。強化可能な項目は初期の銃や各種ステージ内で入手できるパワーアップ類の効果の上昇等があり、特殊な物だと、「主人公の移動速度を永続的に強化する」、「コンボ持続時間の延長」というものもある。

[h1][b]【悪い点】[/b][/h1]

◆ 部屋の中で敵を全滅させるゲームなので仕様が無いが、ステージ内のギミック自体に違いはあるものの、ステージが全体的に似たり寄ったりになっている。

◆ ゲームの進行には特に影響はないが、日本語化時の翻訳が少し雑になっており、時々主人公と研究員の会話が微妙に噛み合っていない場合もある。

[h1][b]【総評】[/b][/h1]

全体的に難易度はそれほど高くなく、ミニゲーム感覚でプレイできるシューティングゲームになっているので、シューティング系初心者にもオススメだ。ただし、ステージの評価を最大にする等のやり込みを行わない場合は少しボリューム不足に感じるかもしれない。

プレイ動画をアップしているので、気になった方は[u][url=https://youtu.be/r-VwDp0x3d8]こちら[/url][/u]を参考までにどうぞ。

39517664.review:
Один из немногих случаев, когда [b]набор скриншотов от разработчиков на странице магазина очень информативен[/b]. По идее, игрокам остается только пять звезд накидывать и предлагать любоваться остальным этой историей, а не за обзоры или краткие отзывы садиться. Я не зря написал про "любоваться" - надо именно любоваться историей, выжимать из нее добрые красочные эмоции и пережить скромный сюжет кампании за несколько часов, а не воспринимать игру как убийцу времени.

Тем более перед нами переведенный в формат игре возникший в чьем-то сознании комикс с мистером пылесосом и мистером телевизором (а иногда их два), который смело из укрытий будет доставать вам ящики с оружием и тактическим снаряжением.

[b]Что сказать про игровой процесс?[/b] Доводим перебежки до автоматизма. Любуемся на скорости монстрами и забываем, что выделенные 2 с половиной минуты улетучиваются. Игра не грузит, оружие и специальные маневры (особенности) монстров запоминаются достаточно быстро. Бросаем уровень, отключаем игру, успокаиваемся и на свежую голову со свежими реакциями вновь бросаемся в бой.
